review_blob: Bottle to glass.  Pours golden with a small white head.  Tiny lacings left along the glass.  Aroma is a bit off putting when I crack the first bottle open, but I either get used to it, or it was a skunk was, because I dont notice it after that.  Dry, mostly bitter with a bit of sweetness on the finish.  Has a classic pilsner profile.  Not bad at all.
Honestly, it tastes just like Chimey Red.  Red my review on that.  I aint even lying.

Bottle.  Pours a clear golden, with a non substantial white head.   Not a lot of aroma - some malt, a tiny bit of hops, and maybe corn(?).  Taste is malty with some sweetness on the back end.  Very crisp and clean.  Refreshing.  Medium to thin bodied.  Its an average beer.  Would go well with many dishes or a nice treat after doing yard work on a hot day.

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: Bottle.  Pours a copper/amber with a decent, long lasting one finger head.  Aroma is sweet malts, toasty.  Taste is more sweetened malts, some roastiness, nuts.  Finishes bitter.  Mild/medium bodied.  Well after the finish, it does leave an odd peanut like taste lingering.  Not sure what the deal is with that - but its not overly strong.  Still, odd.  Ok offering, nothing great.

Bottle.  Pours a dark red.  Thin off white head.  Aroma is sweet, sugary and belgian yeasty.  It has a very weak, thin belgian yeast flavor.  Watery.  A bit hoppy in the finish.  Some bubblegum.  A little sweet.  Highly inoffensive.  Not a big flavor profile.  Very thin mouthfeel.  I think this is barely an abbey ale.  Not sure what they are doing with this one.  Poor effort.  Although, it looks great in the glass.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque amber/orange.  Very small, thin white head.  Aroma is hops, pine, grapefruit, apricot - some peaches, maybe.  Taste is much the same.  Starts with some malt up front but quickly turns dry and hoppy.  I can really taste sweet fruit (peaches, predominantly) as well, coming through the finish.   Thin in body, but not watery.  A small amount of bitterness lingers, but it finishes very clean.  Very good.

Bottle (bottled 3/14).   Pours a cloudy lemon yellow.  Thick white head that quickly thins out, but leaves foamy lacing all over the glass.  Smell is grass, pine, lemons, grapefruit.  Very citrusy aroma.  Taste floral, lemons.  Initially sweet but quickly turns bitter.  The finish lingers.  Medium body.  Very refreshing.  If I had to make a comparison, its like a lemony/citrus version of their APA, and less bitter.  Very good.

Pours thick, dark golden and opaque.  Thin but long lasting white head.  Aroma is pine, citrus, grass and grapefruit.  Taste is more of the same, but with a sweet malty backbone.  The taste lingers - a mixture of sweet malty goodness and bitter hops.  Med. thick mouthfeel.  Not as carbonated as it looks.  Very good.  No taste of alcohol for me.  A delight.

Pours a dark gold/amber with a puffy white head.  Aroma is pine, grass and citrus.  Taste is pine, lemon, oranges, grass,   A nice malt backbone - maybe some very light caramel there.  Finishes with a lingering bitterness, with a slight sweet end.  Thick mouthfeel, almost oily to me.  Average carbonation.  Leaves white lacings on the glass as it goes down.  Very, very good.
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2011

Bottle to glass.  Pours golden, with a white head that quickly goes away.  Aroma is bready, malt and some hops.  Taste is a strong malt character, nutty.  Very crisp.  Finishes with a small amount of bitterness.  It lingers.  Very good, very refreshing.

Pours hazy golden with a lively, foamy, big white head.  Not a lot of aroma - banana, a little clove, maybe a light citrus on the nose.  Taste is sublime - banana, clove, a hint of lemon/citrus.  Finishes a tad bitter but very clean.   Taste lingers.  Moderate carbonation, a tad fizzy.  Very refreshing and easy to drink.  Can easily drink a lot of these - really quenches your thirst.  Very good.

Bottle to glass.  Pours an opaque amber.  Short lasting one finger light cappiccino head.  Smell is grass and pine and a small whiff of dark malts.  Taste is a balance of piney hops and once again, a bit of dark malt in the backbone.  I can taste a bit of bitter citrus as well.  Good carbonation.  Feels surprisingly thick for a lower alcohol beer.  Very good

Bottle to glass.  Pours a dark golden with a lasting, thick one finger head.  Aroma is pine, citrus, grass.  Taste is bitter, piney, with a citrus background. I can taste more and more lemons and orange zest as I drink it.   Has a rich mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation.  The bitterness lingers.  Very good.  Only a notch below the AIPA special release.

Bottle to glass.  Pours clear copper/yellow.  Small white head.  Aroma is rather plain - a bit hoppy, pine, grass and some malty caramel.  Taste is much the same - some caramel malts with a bitter hoppy finish.  Very refreshing.  Finishes dry and bitter.  A perfectly good session beer.  It is what it is.
beer_name: Big Sky Scape Goat Pale Ale

review_blob: Bottle to snifter.  Pours jet black with a small mocha head.  Little to no carbonation.  Smells of bitter dark chocolate and dark coffee - like a sumatra blend of coffee, I think.  Taste is sublime - dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts.  Finishes dry with some bitterness.  Taste lingers.  No alcohol at all noticed.  Really reminds you of breakfast.  Mouthfeel not as thick as I would have thought, but still great.   The finest stout Ive ever had.  Almost perfect.  Sublime.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange.  Thick white 2 finger head.  Smell is grapefruit, grass and pine.  Taste is bitter with a bit of citrus and grapefruit.  Finishes mildly dry.  Flavor lingers a bit.  Moderate mouthfeel.  Overall a very bitter and hoppy beer.  Very impressive IPA.  Very easy to drink and refreshing.  Love it.

Bottle.  Pours clear yellow.  White head.  Smells of grapfruit, citrus and hops.  Taste is citrus and a hoppy bitterness, but the hoppiness is a tad low compared to the great IPAs.  Surprisingly thin mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation.  Very refreshing.  Im a tad disappointed, but a good beer all the same.

Bottle.  Pours a darker yellow with an off white head, leaves lacings all over the glass.  Aroma is citrus, grapfruit, hoppy.  Taste is much of the same - piney, grapefruit and citrus with some malt and caramel character in the background.  Extremely well balanced.  Very refreshing.  Finishes dry Medium body.  Shame this is only available in limited quantities during the summer.  Its outstanding.

Bottle to snifter.  Enjoying this with an average cigar (Gurkha Grand Reserve, which goes nicely, btw).  Pours motor oil black, viscous. Low carbonation.  Very small mocha head where it touches the glass.  Smell is of coffee, chocolate and licorice.  Taste is dark chocolate, a bit of coffee.  Sweet.  No hint of alcohol for me.  Very oily and sticky on the palate.  A bit of a hoppy, bitter finish, but very sublte.  Outstanding.

Bottle.  Pours midnight, pitch black with no head.  Little carbonation.  I dont get a lot of aroma - its mostly a coffee, charred wood aroma.  Taste is a very rich coffee, smokey flavor with a bitter finish.  Oily and thick on the palate.  No taste of booze at all.  Very good for weasel shit.

Bottle.  Pours a dark, opaque, almost black with a tiny mocha head that leaves a lot of lacing on the glass.  Smell is chocolate, coffee, licorice, vanilla.  Tastes the same, with a small hoppy yet sweet finish. A bit dry.  Feels slick and oily.  Not an "in your face" type of stout, but very subtle flavors.  Exceptional.  As a bonus, its priced great in my area and easily available.

Bottle into trappist glass.  Pours a deep, dark, murky brown with an off white, 2 finger head.  Appears nicely carbonated.  Leaves nice lacings on the glass.  Boozey aroma.  Taste is a boozy warming and belgian yeasty goodness.  As I let the glass sit, it becomes less boozy, however.  Medium carbonation, medium body.   Very good, but I much prefer Chimay or Rochefort in regards to this style.

Bottle to glass.  Pours oily, viscous black with barely any head (small lacings of mocha are present, however).  Heavy mocha lacing are left on the glass.   Smell is coffee and perhaps a burnt, smokey character.  Taste is coffee with a hoppy and bitter finish.  Dry.  No alcohol whatsoever.  A perfect blend of hops and coffee, if I may say.  Very thick and oily mouthfeel.  The hoppy bitterness lingers.  Outstanding!
beer_name: North Coast Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob: Poured into trappist glass from bottle.  Golden orange with a fluffy, thick white head.  Smells sweet and citrus, with some doughy undernotes.  Taste is the same - sweet, citrus, a bit of doughy bread.  Finishes a bit bitter and very dry.  Not overly thick.  Med/high carbonation.  Very good, but a bit behind other trappists brews.

Bottle to trappist glass.  Appearance is dark, murky brown with a brownish white head.  Smell is caramel and belgian yeast, burnt sugar.  Taste is sublime - rich, dark caramel, almost a brown sugar flavor.  Very rich and creamy.  No taste of booze for me.  Very creamy, almost like drinking velvet or silk.  Finish is warm and pleasing.  This bottle was just over a year old.  By far, the finest brew Ive had to date, but the price is hideous ($6.99 an 11.2oz bottle).
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2011

Bottle.  Pours an amber - caramel color with a white head that leaves thick lacing on the glass.  Aroma is malty with a small bit of hops.  Taste is the same. Feels creamy to the palate.  Slightly bitter/dry finish.  Very good pale ale.  Not sure why it gets such low ratings.  Definately a session beer, but retains very good flavor and is refreshing.    Definately gonna pick this up again.

Bottle.  Pours thick, oily black with a smallm mocha head.  Aroma is booze, cocoa, coffee, dark malts and chocolates.  Taste is more of the same - booze, cocoa, coffee, dark chocolates.  Feels slick and oily on the palate.  Finishes sour with a strong coffee flavor.  Low carbonation.  Except for the finish, not bad.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy pale gold.  Thick white head with lots of carbonation in it.  Smells of cirtus, especially lemon and orange with a small hint of spice.  The dominant flavors are orange and lemon, with a bit of clove, also a mix of sweet and sour.  Finishes sour and stays with you.    Body to me is light but creamy.  Average carbonation.  Very good.

Bottle.  Pours black with a long lasting off white head that leaves wonderful lacing.  Aroma is a bit of roast malt, maybe a little chocolate.  Dont really get much of an aroma, honestly.  Taste is highly inoffensive - there aint much going on.  It looks to be creamy and thick, but its a tad watery and bland.  A bit of roasted malts, chocoate and even some milk (?).  Maybe a bit of coffee - I was surprised how little taste it had.  Light and easy to drink.  A milky-like finish.  Again, I dont detect much in the finish.  As inoffensive and bland as it is, it surprisngly easy to drink and sublte.  While it seems like I would score this a lot lower, I actually kind of liked it.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy, hazy yellow with a bright, white head that lingers.  Smells of fruit, lemon, banana, dough.  Taste is more of the same but with a bit of spice and yeast.  Finishes sweet with banana and citrus.  Medium to high carbonation.  Doesnt stand out in one particular area, but very refreshing and a surprisingly good effort by a local brewer.

Bottle.  Pours golden, white head, nice lacing.  Aroma is citrus, fruit, pine.  Taste is an outstanding balance of hoppy bitterness and citrus.  Lively texture, lite body and carbonation.  Finishes bitter and dry with a hint of citrus.  Very clean finish.  Great for the heat of summer, very refreshing.
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2011

Bottle into Trappist glass.   Pours dark reddish-brown, little to no head.  Smells of dark malts and fruit.  Taste is sweet, yeasty with moderate carbonation.  I can see the port wine reference with each taste.  Medium body.  Warms a bit going down, but not boozy.  Outstanding beer.

Pured into a Trappist glass.  Hazy, amber color.  Overriding smell of alcohol.  Taste is strongly boozy.  Perhaps some dark fruits and caramel tastes underneath it all, but its overbearingly boozy.  I really like a lot of Boulevard beer, but this just doesnt do it for me.  Im not one to be afraid of an overly boozy brew, but this just ruins the subteties.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - The Sixth Glass Quadrupel

review_blob: Outstanding!  Pours dark, reddish - brown color.  Off-white head with nice lacings.  Sweet aroma.  Taste is sweet with a slight bitterness, some dark fruits.  Medium carbonation.  Slightly bitter aftertaste.  Medium body.  Outstanding brew.  Not overly filling, which I like in a dubbel.  Very easy to drink.  Probably my favorite beer.

I just dont know about this one.  Pours beautiful golden with small white head.  A slight, spicey, fruity aroma. Taste is .... odd, to say the least.  Very peppery, spicey and clove.  Taste like they actually dumped pepper in the bottle.  Slightly sweet finish and aftertase.  I want to like it but, meh.  Average at best.

Pours deep, dark reddish brown.  Earthy yet surprisingly sweet aroma.  Flavor is yeast and spices, slightly sweet.  Perhaps a bit of caramel.  Finishes dry and sweet - also pleasingly bitter.   A little bit of alcohol taste afterwards, but not unpleasant or overly strong.  The flavor really stays with you afterwards.  Outstanding brew.  Definately need to at least try this once.  Outstanding at its price and availability.

Pours dark and hazy gold-yellow.  Citrus, spicey aroma with a hint of dough.  Taste is of fruit, wheat, spice and a bit of earthiness - a lot of subtleties here I have a hard time putting into words.   High carbonation, medium body.  It really does hide the higher ABV, with a very smoothe finish.  Outstanding beer.  A little more wheaty than other Tripels Ive had, but overall, an excellent, well balanced brew.

On tap;  Citrus aroma with a hint of spice and wheat to it.  Cloudy, amber body.  Large, white head.  Taste is banana, wheat, and a little sweetness.  Nicely carbonated and finishes dry but sweet.  Medium body.  Outstanding flavor and extremely drinkable.  My favorite Hefe.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2011
